sentences.sentence: Election agenda The Prime Minister does not acknowledge the underlying productivity problem in the economy, and describes reform as a vanity project.With almost six weeks until election day, all the public opinion polls have Labor well ahead.

But as the polls tighten - and inevitably they will - stories will abound that Scott Morrison is roaring home in a possible repeat of his "miracle" 2019 election victory.Recent polls report Labor maintaining a budget-defying lead of at least 54-46.

The Ipsos poll commissioned by The Australian Financial Review estimated the Labor lead to be 55-45, based on the 2019 preference flows.My prediction of a tightening is based on a simple statistical observation: at no time since 1975 has either party gained 55 per cent of the two-party preferred vote.A second reality check is the early flow of money: the election betting has Labor ahead in just nine seats, and in most of these only slightly so.

Complicating the equation, independents are challenging Coalition MPs in several normally safe seats.How will the election campaign unfold?Coalition tacticians will seek to portray Labor as a risk to the economy.
They always do.
Morrison and his economic ministers will insist that taxes, spending, deficits and debts will always be higher under Labor.The facts say otherwise.

Tables published in this year's main budget document reveal the Howard government was the highest-taxing government in the past half century, closely followed by the Morrison government.What about spending?

The Morrison government has outspent the previous Labor government, even if the pandemic years are excluded from its record and the GFC stimulus spending is included in Labor's tally.And before the pandemic struck, the Morrison government had almost doubled the Commonwealth's net debt.

By the end of this year, it will have trebled the debt.The Coalition has already had a go at portraying Labor as weak on national security, its surrogates funding mobile billboards depicting President Xi Jinping casting a vote for Labor.

And Morrison used parliamentary privilege to brand the deputy Labor leader the "Manchurian candidate".Morrison's anti-China attacks are a strange way of managing our relationship with by far the biggest buyer of Australian exports.Labor will emphasise its caring credentials: Medicare, childcare and aged care.

And it will point out that the budget forecasts real wages to fall at least until 2025 as workers' pay fails to keep pace with the cost of living.Efforts to goad Labor into announcing expensive new policies by alleging Anthony Albanese has adopted a small-target strategy will not work.

Labor has abandoned its proposal to broaden the taxation of family trusts, the last remaining controversial tax change it took to the 2019 election.Announcing a large suite of unfunded spending policies would make Labor the big target its opponents want it to be.Readers of The Australian Financial Review might feel frustrated that neither side has laid out a comprehensive economic reform program aimed at lifting productivity and, with it, future living standards.Since its time in power, the Morrison government has not even acknowledged we have an underlying economic problem.

Australia's woeful productivity performance during the past 10 years has been masked by favourable prices of iron ore, coal and gas.At this year's US midterm elections, the Democrats will probably lose their majority to Trumpian protectionists in one or both houses of Congress.
Donald Trump or his cardboard cut-out will contest the next presidential election.

Responding to Republican nationalism, the Democrats will become more protectionist too.In an increasingly protectionist world, hoping our luck will hold, with customers continuing to buy our exports at top prices, is not an economic strategy.Any successful reform program must start with a national conversation about the problem we are trying to fix.

Bob Hawke and Paul Keating explained at length our problem had become an over-reliance on agricultural exports that were getting hammered by a US-EU trade war.Having accepted this reality, the Australian people backed tough budget cuts and a sweeping economic reform program that yielded the productivity boom of the 1990s.Morrison has been silent on any such conversation, describing economic reforms as vanity exercises.
A national reform summit will be needed after the election to kick off this conversation.
It should be followed by an agreed program of work to inform a new reform agenda.Albanese has committed to such an endeavour, which he calls a jobs summit.
It is a start.
As is Albanese's commitment to govern in the reformist tradition of the Hawke-Keating governments.The Morrison government would be wise to make a similar pre-election commitment.
It has plenty of time to do so.
Six weeks is an eternity in politics.Craig Emerson is managing director of Emerson Economics.
He is director of the APEC Study Centre at RMIT University, a visiting fellow at the ANU and adjunct professor at Victoria University's College of Business.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Election agenda The Prime Minister does not acknowledge the underlying productivity problem in the economy, and describes reform as a vanity project.With almost six weeks until election day, all the public opinion polls have Labor well ahead. But as the polls tighten - and inevitably they will - stories will abound that Scott Morrison is roaring home in a possible repeat of his "miracle" 2019 election victory.Recent polls report Labor maintaining a budget-defying lead of at least 54-46. The Ipsos poll commissioned by The Australian Financial Review estimated the Labor lead to be 55-45, based on the 2019 preference flows.My prediction of a tightening is based on a simple statistical observation: at no time since 1975 has either party gained 55 per cent of the two-party preferred vote.A second reality check is the early flow of money: the election betting has Labor ahead in just nine seats, and in most of these only slightly so. Complicating the equation, independents are challenging Coalition MPs in several normally safe seats.How will the election campaign unfold?Coalition tacticians will seek to portray Labor as a risk to the economy. They always do. Morrison and his economic ministers will insist that taxes, spending, deficits and debts will always be higher under Labor.The facts say otherwise. Tables published in this year's main budget document reveal the Howard government was the highest-taxing government in the past half century, closely followed by the Morrison government.What about spending? The Morrison government has outspent the previous Labor government, even if the pandemic years are excluded from its record and the GFC stimulus spending is included in Labor's tally.And before the pandemic struck, the Morrison government had almost doubled the Commonwealth's net debt. By the end of this year, it will have trebled the debt.The Coalition has already had a go at portraying Labor as weak on national security, its surrogates funding mobile billboards depicting President Xi Jinping casting a vote for Labor. And Morrison used parliamentary privilege to brand the deputy Labor leader the "Manchurian candidate".Morrison's anti-China attacks are a strange way of managing our relationship with by far the biggest buyer of Australian exports.Labor will emphasise its caring credentials: Medicare, childcare and aged care. And it will point out that the budget forecasts real wages to fall at least until 2025 as workers' pay fails to keep pace with the cost of living.Efforts to goad Labor into announcing expensive new policies by alleging Anthony Albanese has adopted a small-target strategy will not work. Labor has abandoned its proposal to broaden the taxation of family trusts, the last remaining controversial tax change it took to the 2019 election.Announcing a large suite of unfunded spending policies would make Labor the big target its opponents want it to be.Readers of The Australian Financial Review might feel frustrated that neither side has laid out a comprehensive economic reform program aimed at lifting productivity and, with it, future living standards.Since its time in power, the Morrison government has not even acknowledged we have an underlying economic problem. Australia's woeful productivity performance during the past 10 years has been masked by favourable prices of iron ore, coal and gas.At this year's US midterm elections, the Democrats will probably lose their majority to Trumpian protectionists in one or both houses of Congress. Donald Trump or his cardboard cut-out will contest the next presidential election. Responding to Republican nationalism, the Democrats will become more protectionist too.In an increasingly protectionist world, hoping our luck will hold, with customers continuing to buy our exports at top prices, is not an economic strategy.Any successful reform program must start with a national conversation about the problem we are trying to fix. Bob Hawke and Paul Keating explained at length our problem had become an over-reliance on agricultural exports that were getting hammered by a US-EU trade war.Having accepted this reality, the Australian people backed tough budget cuts and a sweeping economic reform program that yielded the productivity boom of the 1990s.Morrison has been silent on any such conversation, describing economic reforms as vanity exercises. A national reform summit will be needed after the election to kick off this conversation. It should be followed by an agreed program of work to inform a new reform agenda.Albanese has committed to such an endeavour, which he calls a jobs summit. It is a start. As is Albanese's commitment to govern in the reformist tradition of the Hawke-Keating governments.The Morrison government would be wise to make a similar pre-election commitment. It has plenty of time to do so. Six weeks is an eternity in politics.Craig Emerson is managing director of Emerson Economics. He is director of the APEC Study Centre at RMIT University, a visiting fellow at the ANU and adjunct professor at Victoria University's College of Business.
